results.title: One armed bandit
results.brief_description: Three animated sketches show the dark side of greed. In each sketch a poker machine swallows up those bitten by the gambling bug. No spoken language - sound effects only.

results.title: One and one makes three
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Cockram, Telefeatures, Stella Productions and Mario Andreacchio
results.brief_description: The first in a series of films about parenthood, this film aims to give prospective parents a realistic picture of the problems and joys that come with the new addition to the family: the first child. Many young people slip into parenthood without really knowing what to expect. This film could be appropriately subtitled: ‘What nobody ever told you about having babies’. Presented by Jacki Weaver.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nicholas Cockram, Telefeatures, Stella Productions and Mario Andreacchio

results.title: Once upon a wilderness
results.brief_description: Passages from an early pioneer’s journal illustrate the contrast between the American wilderness then, and the environment today. Shows how the wilderness is being decimated by construction and “progress”, often without thought. Emphasises the importance of attitudes. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Once upon a time
results.creator_credit: Mischa Scorer, Channel 4 and Antelope Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Testament: The Bible and history”.
Part one examines the literal truth of the Old Testament, in particular Genesis,by looking at archaelogical evidence found near the ancient sites of Mesopotamia. These ancient cultures with their parallel “biblical” stories are also discussed. In Part two, the story of Exodus is examined by looking at the historical evidence found in Egypt and how the concept of “God” changed from this time.

results.title: Once upon a time
results.creator_credit: Maxwell Munden, Film Workshop, Central Office of Information and Dennis Shand
results.brief_description: A story of Britain’s contribution to the art of clock-making. The Greenwich Observatory was established during the reign of Charles II.; in 1764 a clock was made which would keep time for months on board ships, and so the problem of longitude was solved. Today, in the age of mass production, Britain’s clockwork industry maintains its high standards of precision and reliability.

results.title: On your own
results.brief_description: Explores the wide range of practical subjects covered in the education curriculum for high schools and junior colleges. Some of the many subjects covered include comparative shopping, home ownership vs renting, baking low cost bread, repairing old furniture, credit and money management, family relations, operating a child care centre on campus, and other pertinent studies. Student response is evident in lively group discussions and in scenes filmed in the actual classroom.

results.title: On writing
results.creator_credit: Alexander Milsky, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Alan Marshall: author and man”.
Though afflicted by sickness and suffering at an early age, Marshall had a happy childhood. He began to write at the age of ten. He read widely and was influenced by various authors, though his stories usually begin from small everyday incidents or remarks. He offers some advice to young writers.
